{{also|brot|brót|bröt|brøt|Brot.}} ==Central Franconian== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|gmw-cfr|Brut}} {{i|Ripuarian, northern Moselle Franconian}} ===Noun=== {{head|gmw-cfr|noun|g=n}} # {{lb|gmw-cfr|southern|_|Moselle Franconian}} [[bread]] # {{lb|gmw-cfr|same region}} [[loaf]] of bread ---- ==German== {{slim-wikipedia|lang=de}} [[Image:Breads.jpg|thumb|Zwei '''Brote''' — Two '''loaves of bread''' (2)]] [[Image:Rye bread.JPG|thumb|Mehrere Scheiben Roggen'''brot''' — Several slices of rye '''bread''' (1)]] ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|Brod}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|brōt}}, from {{inh|de|goh|brōt}} (attested since the 8th century), from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*braudą}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*bʰrew-||to seethe, to boil}}. Originally, the meaning of ''Brot'' was ''"what has been fermented, leaven"'' and may be a nominal derivative from {{cog|gem-pro|*brewwaną||to brew}} (whence German {{m|de|brauen}}). It replaced the older {{m|de|Laib||loaf}} which was the more common term in Old High German (compare the use of {{m|ang|hlāf}} and {{m|ang|brēad}} in Old English).Pfeifer, Wolfgang. 1995, 2005. ''Etymologisches Wörterbuch des Deutschen.'' München: dtv. {{ISBN|3423325119}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/bʁoːt/}} * {{audio|de|De-Brot.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-Brot.ogg|audio (Austria)}} * {{rhymes|de|oːt}} *
